title: Is Madrid's Barrio de Salamanca too nice for tourists?
text:
If you're willing to stand in line, the new Gourmet Experience food court at the El Corte Inglés department store at Calle Serrano 52 claims seven Michelin stars among its seventh-floor food-stall vendors. NYT by Andrew Ferren It's not often that a prime and picturesque neighbourhood gets the snub from travellers because its shops, restaurants and other establishments are considered too nice. But that's what some visitors do with Barrio de Salamanca in Madrid, perhaps the city's toniest enclave, often (and rather aptly) compared to the Upper East Side of Manhattan.
While Salamanca's streets aren't paved with gold, the barrio does support a surprising density of jewellers, galleries, antiques dealers and luxury fashion houses where prices are, more often than not, sky high. On weekday mornings, rivers of tartan course along the sidewalks as uniformed children scamper off to the area's many private schools.
Cultural treasures But for anyone hoping to savour the true essence of Madrid, even upper-crust Barrio de Salamanca has price points ranging from modest to free. Among its cultural treasures is the newly-renovated Museo Arqueologico Nacional –admission €3 (about $5) – which showcases the art and history of the country's first indigenous peoples as well as the waves of colonisers – Greek, Roman, Moorish – who came here from across the Mediterranean.
The newly-renovated Museo Arqueologico Nacional showcases the art and history of Spain's first indigenous peoples as well as the waves of colonisers. NYT If you prefer your art a bit more recent, head straight up Calle Serrano to the Museo Lázaro-Galdiano (admission €6, with a free hour each afternoon) where works by the likes of El Greco, Murillo and Goya share galleries with decorative arts. Other neighbourhood cultural beacons include the Fundación Carlos de Amberes and the Fundación Juan March; both are free and offer temporary exhibitions, concerts and lectures.
Seven Michelin stars Gastronomically speaking, the neighbourhood is equally varied. Drop into Jurucha for tapas and aperitifs (€2 to €3), and, as winter's chill sets in, consider Taberna de la Daniela for a siesta-inducing cocido, the traditional Madrileño stew of garbanzos, vegetables and pork that is served in three courses for €26.50.
If a nap is not in your future, try Magasand, the favoured gathering spot for fashionistas who snack on sandwiches (€5 to €7) while perusing design magazines. If you're willing to stand in line, the new Gourmet Experience food court at the El Corte Inglés department store at Calle Serrano 52 claims seven Michelin stars among its seventh-floor food-stall vendors, with outlets by Jordi Roca, Roberto Ruiz and David Muñoz. A meal at Muñoz's sit-down StreetXO costs around €40; you can graze at the other stalls for less.
The gourmet food court at El Corte Ingles. NYT Confiteria Rialto has been selling crisp and delicate Marcona-almond and chocolate moscovita wafers (250 grams, for €12) for more than 80 years. At La Húngara, it's all about the sweet charms (chocolate and raspberry 10 ways) of Austro-Hungarian desserts, which range in price from €1.50 to €10.
Fast and slow fashion For wearable souvenirs, Renatta & Go (T-shirts start about €15) has chic casual wear for women and girls, and all that glitters is merely gold-plated at Aristocrazy (rings from €50), which does a booming business in costume jewellery.
Last year, the Spanish fast-fashion emporium Zara (dresses from €30) opened an elegant and very full-service new flagship on Calle Serrano, and its Massimo Dutti division has restarted a bespoke menswear line (custom suits from €400) under the aegis of society style maven Rafael Medina Abascal, bringing a new clientele to the brand.
With rings from €50, Aristocrazy does a booming business in costume jewellery. NYT Other local haberdashers like Lander Urquijo and Patch Mercantile's Curro Ariza do their part to keep the local gentry looking fine at reasonable prices (shirts, €40 ti €90 euros) especially considering the quality of the fabrics and tailoring.
So whether your budget is €20, €200 or €2,000 per day, Madrid's Barrio de Salamanca is worth getting to know.
